NATIONAL NEWS






President Bush's Appearance at Browns Ferry Pays Tribute to Nuclear Energy's Revitalization



President Bush toured the Browns Ferry nuclear power plant in Decatur, Ala., today to acknowledge the completion of the refurbishment one month ago of the 1,150-megawatt Browns Ferry 1 reactor. This was President Bush's third visit to a nuclear power plant since June 2005. Following is a statement from Frank L. 'Skip' Bowman, the Nuclear Energy Institute's president and chief executive officer. ...


Jun 21, 2007 PR Newswire



Energy Transfer Declares Increase in Unitholder Distributions



DALLAS--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Energy Transfer Partners, L.P. (NYSE: ETP) and Energy Transfer Equity, L.P. (NYSE: ETE) today announced their respective quarterly distribution increases. ETP has approved its new quarterly distribution of $0.80625 per unit ($3.225 annualized) on ETPs outstanding limited partner interests for the quarter ended May 31, 2007. The new quarterly distribution of $0.80625 per ...


Jun 21, 2007 Business Wire



PJM Authorizes Construction of $2.9 Billion in Transmission Additions and Upgrades



The PJM Interconnection Board today authorized $2.9 billion in electric transmission upgrades and additions, including two major new transmission lines. The authorization came with the Board's approval of changes to PJM's Regional Transmission Expansion Plan, which maintains the reliability of the power supply system serving 51 million people in 13 states and the District of Columbia.

Utility-line accidents increasing: Workers are asked to call before digging



Jun. 22--The phone and power companies say they have been dealing with a high rate of accidents resulting from people digging up underground service lines. But blackouts and service disruptions aren't the only result of workers and homeowners coming into contact with utilities. Power lines are a lethal threat to cable installers, construction workers and the unaware homeowner trimming a tree or ...


Jun 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Storms cut power to nearly 9,000 in Western Pa.



Jun. 22--Evening storms Thursday left more than 3,600 Allegheny Power customers without electricity in Westmoreland and Indiana counties, according to a utility Web site and spokesman.  As of 6 p.m., the electricity provider reported 3,112 customers without service in Westmoreland and 522 users without power in Indiana. Overall, 8,800 customers in southwestern Pennsylvania were without power as ...


Jun 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



KeySpan to address plant concerns



Jun. 22--KeySpan Corp., the owner of more than two dozen former utility gas-plant sites on Long Island, yesterday sought to allay concerns about one of the largest sites as community members prepare to meet about it in Hempstead next week.  The Hempstead manufactured natural gas plant, near Intersection and North Franklin streets, spawned a nearly 4,000-by 600-foot plume from the 7.5 acre site, a ...


Jun 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Alternative energy sellers court Duke



Jun. 22--CHARLOTTE -- Duke Energy said that about 70 alternative energy providers submitted proposals to sell power to the Charlotte-based utility. Duke is accepting proposals as part of the company's plan to offset 1,700 megawatts of conventional electricity, the equivalent of several power plants. It will accept bids until July 27 and plans to negotiate contracts this year for approval by the ...


Jun 22, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Charged up over power lines: McKinney: Neighbors protest substation, take fight to PUC



Jun. 21--MCKINNEY -- Moms and dads sat in the City Council chambers until no seats were left; then they stood in the back, their strollers blocking the aisles.  Residents of two neighborhoods had come in force to protest power-line towers that could be built a few hundred feet from their back yards. A power substation covering several acres could also be part of the package.


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Scientists call for more research on coal



Jun. 21--The federal government should quadruple annual funding for coal research to $190 million to make better use of the nation's resources and minimize the impact on the environment, the National Research Council says. More than half of the nation's electricity comes from coal, a fuel that will help satisfy the country's energy appetite for decades. But the extent to which it will be relied ...


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Plan to keep steam utility going as bankruptcy court OKs temporary fix



Jun. 21--A U.S. bankruptcy judge has approved a temporary plan to keep Akron Thermal in business through July 9.  Judge Marilyn Shea-Stonum will allow the indebted steam utility to use cash collateral to pay its 45 employees and resume coal purchases to fuel its boilers. Akron Thermal Limited Partnership filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday, on the eve of an eviction from the plant that ...


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Power is back on in Madison Heights



Jun. 21--A circuit problem caused 900 customers in Madison Heights to lose power this morning, said Eileen Dixon, a DTE Energy spokeswoman. She said power was restored by 2:42 p.m.  The problem hit around 9:30 a.m. in the area of 12 Mile Road and Stephenson Highway. The cause of the outage is under investigation.


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Review on gas terminal to go on



Jun. 21--WASHINGTON -- Legislation that would have halted federal regulators' review of the proposed Broadwater liquid natural gas terminal in Long Island Sound failed to gain House support yesterday.  An amendment to the House energy bill introduced by Rep. Tim Bishop (D-Southampton) would have barred the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from using any federal funds next year to continue ...

Senate rejects LNG plant measure: Amendment would have allowed state to stop Dundalk terminal



Jun. 21--WASHINGTON -- The Senate has rejected a measure that would have allowed opponents of the liquefied natural gas terminal proposed for Sparrows Point to defeat the project.  Sen. Benjamin L. Cardin had introduced the measure to restore to states the authority to block new LNG terminals after residents rose up against plans to build the facility on the former site of the Bethlehem Steel ...


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Ex-Enron official settles for $300,000



Jun. 21--A former top Enron executive who was entangled in a string of company deals that drew the attention of regulators and prosecutors agreed today to pay $300,000 to settle civil allegations.  Jeff McMahon, who replaced Andrew Fastow as finance chief during the company's spiral into bankruptcy in late 2001, neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing as part of the settlement with the Securities ...


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Jordan braces for heatwave: Electricity demand to reach record levels



Jun. 21--AMMAN -- A huge increase in demand for electricity to power fans and air-conditioning systems is expected over the weekend as the Kingdom faces its first heatwave of the summer.  A hot mass coming from the Arabian Peninsula is expected to reach the country on Friday, raising temperatures in Amman to around 39  C. The heatwave, which is expected to last until the middle of next week, will ...

Wind turbine locations sent back to board



Jun. 21--The location of nine turbines in the Oliver Wind II project will be altered from the original plan, requiring a return of the project to the Oliver County Planning and Zoning Commission next week.  Oliver Wind II will go into full-blown construction soon, but changes with landowners and design mean that some of the wind turbines will be moved outside of the previously approved project ...


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



PSC hiring consultants to study rate options



Jun. 21--State utility regulators said yesterday that they are looking to hire several industry consultants to help them study options for reducing electricity rates in Maryland.  The cluster of studies was required in legislation passed earlier this year in response to concerns about rising electric rates hitting customers of Baltimore Gas and Electric Co.


Jun 21, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News





New Jersey passes CO2 "leakage" legislation supported by Governor



New York, New York (Platts)--22Jun2007 The New Jersey Legislature passed the Global Warming Response Act late Thursday evening, requiring mandatory reductions of greenhouse gas emissions to below 1990 levels by 2020, and to 80% below 2006 levels by 2050. The state Department of Environmental Protection will determine how far below 1990 levels emissions will fall when it implements the measure, ...

2 Major Mid-Atlantic Power Lines Get Key Endorsement Marc Levy HARRISBURG, Pa. (AP) - Two proposals for major mid-Atlantic power transmission lines received critical endorsements Friday from the company that operates the mid-Atlantic electricity grid. The proposed high-voltage lines, which would cost more than $2.7 billion, are aimed at bringing surplus electricity from coal-fired power plants in ...

BEIJING // It was only three months ago that international energy officials revised a prediction that China would surpass the United States as the world's largest producer of greenhouse gases by 2009 or 2010. German firm ventures into power project in Pakistan



- Pakistan's top motorcycle manufacturer and a leading German diesel engine provider have agreed to set up a commercial power plant in the country's central Punjab province to produce 450 MW. Atlas Honda Limited of Pakistan and MAN Diesel Group of Germany will build the electricity generation unit near the city of Shiekhupura, 75 kilometres west of the Punjab capital Lahore, in two phases.
